awd_abstract_narration:
Brain-computer interfaces (BCIs) are an emerging research area that might profoundly benefit people with severe motor loss and have potential applications in other situations where physical and voice interfaces are impractical.  This project will develop techniques for using ultrasound imaging to measure and interpret brain activity and integrate ultrasound derived information with existing electroencephalography (EEG)-based techniques.  Doing this will provide faster and more precise measures of brain activity compared to existing techniques.  It will also allow for the integration of sub-cortical information into BCIs, information that EEG systems cannot provide.  To achieve this goal, portable ultrasound helmet prototypes will be developed and solutions to transcranial ultrasound image quality problems will be resolved, which will also prove useful for medical ultrasound more generally.  The helmet will advance the feasibility of mobile brain activity measurements.  Along with the development and prototyping of an ultrasound BCI device, the development of new algorithms to integrate ultrasound and EEG signals will lead to new techniques for both understanding brain activity and using it to interact with computers.  The work will also provide the basis for modernizing and creating several new courses around the intersection of machine learning and biomedical signal processing, as well as providing research opportunities for outreach programs that involve high school students from underrepresented groups in STEM.

The project will be organized around several main activities.  The first activity is to develop high-dynamic range ultrasound imaging methods for transcranial ultrasound.  This will include the integration of multiple ultrasound transducer arrays and development of a new beamforming strategy utilizing iterative multi-stage regularization supported by deep learning methods to remove high-amplitude noise while preserving small signal variations corresponding to blood flow.  The second activity is to use the imaging methods to support an adaptive demodulation technique enabling non-contrast functional ultrasound analyses without contrast agents at low transducer frequencies appropriate for human transcranial imaging.  The third activity is to develop a wearable helmet that captures both ultrasound and EEG signals together.  The ultrasound and EEG will be physically registered using a new probe that will serve as both an EEG and an ultrasonic point source.  The helmet data will be used to develop both ultrasound-only and integrated (EEG plus ultrasound) algorithms for detecting brain states that computer systems can use either as direct commands or as input to adapt their behavior to a user's current brain state.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project’s intention was to explore multi-modal brain computer interfaces that utilized both transcranial functional ultrasound and EEG. Our original hypothesis centered around the complementary strengths of the two methods. However, the transcranial functional ultrasound task by itself was sufficiently challenging that we focused entirely on that aspect of the brain computer interface problem, so while we did not meet all original goals, we achieved some very notable outcomes that we are happy to share.

The primary achievement of the proposal is the successful demonstration of transcranial functional ultrasound, which represents a first step towards a fully, non-invasive ultrasound brain-computer interface. Our demonstration focused on a breath-hold task that is a common well-characterized functional task. We performed our task on thirteen subjects, and we achieved an average Pearson’s correlation of 0.58 between the transcranial functional ultrasound measurement and the oxygen saturation. We realized similar results when correlating against the task’s block design. We were excited by this outcome because our correlation levels mirror fMRI correlation levels for the same task. This primary outcome demonstrates that transcranial functional ultrasound is not just a theoretical possibility but a practical reality in adult humans with mature skulls.

While the above demonstration is our primary outcome, this result emerges from a series of extremely important, innovative developments by post-docs, graduate students, undergraduate students and high school students. These developments are ongoing, but we briefly summarize the scope of the necessary developments. First, we developed a new way to transmit ultrasound energy into the body to improve the quality of the signal. We call this coded transmission method compound Barker codes. Second, we developed new ways to filter the signal to more carefully separate the signal coming from tissue from the signal returning from the blood that carries the functional information. Third, we developed enhanced algorithms for making ultrasound images. These methods are less sensitive to the extra noise produced by the skull. Fourth, we developed a series of devices and systems to help us better acquire the transcranial functional ultrasound data. These contributions were disseminated to the public through publicly available journal articles. We also disseminated these developments through talks to industry partners, conferences and other universities. The undergraduate students that were part of this project presented their work in similar venues but also at student design symposia. Based on citations received, our work’s public communications showed impact within the most immediately adjacent scientific community and wider impact on the broader scientific community. These efforts represent the bulk of the project’s intellectual impact.

Beyond the intellectual merit, this effort had a range of broader impacts. This includes the potential impact of our breakthroughs for future scientific insights and impact on individuals with a variety of neurological impairments that could benefit from a brain computer interface. Additionally, the project itself included engagement with the School for Science and Math at Vanderbilt (SSMV). Our outreach to SSMV involved interactions with more than 100 high school students. As part of our work with the SSMV, we also hosted a number of individual high school students for 18-month internships in the lab. In addition to high school students, we hosted several undergraduate students on research projects, and we worked with two senior design teams.

In conclusion, this project was ultimately successful even if the final outcomes did not exactly match all aspects of the initial proposal. Specifically, we were able to construct the necessary technological innovations to successfully demonstrate the most speculative aspects of the proposed work, and we believe that this sets the stage well for continued pursuits in ultrasound-based computer interfaces.
